A man of great energy, physical vigor, and fond of outdoor life and wholesome sports, he is a type of that sturdy manhood which is admired by the young men of our country. Of good birth and culture, he is far from being 311 aristocrat, and is as much at home with the rough cowboys of our western plains as he is with statesmen and leaders of public opinion. He evidently aims to adapt himself to every new situation and emergency.

Mr. Roosevelt entered upon the responsible duties of President upon the death of the martyred and lamented McKinley.
